{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient is a 56-year-old man with subacute back pain that is worse at night. He has a history of non-small cell lung cancer that was successfully treated. The pain started after an amateur weight-lifting competition. On physical exam, there is point tenderness along the lumbosacral area. Given the patient's age, history of cancer, and the presence of point tenderness, the most likely imaging finding in this patient is lytic lesions of the lumbar spine. These lytic lesions could be indicative of metastatic disease from the lung cancer.", "answer_choice": "B"}
